com.jayway.restassured.internal

Class RestAssuredResponseOptionsImpl<R extends ResponseOptions<R>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jayway.restassured.internal.RestAssuredResponseOptionsImpl<R>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ExtractableResponse<R>, ResponseBodyData, ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MockMvcRestAssuredResponseImpl, RestAssuredResponseImpl

    public class RestAssuredResponseOptionsImpl<R extends ResponseOptions<R>>
extends Object
implements ExtractableResponse<R>
    We delegate to the groovy impl here because the Groovy impl messes up generics (see e.g. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11395527/groovy-generics-failure) and thus we cannot let the Groovy implementation implement our interfaces directly.

        public String header(String name)
        Description copied from interface: ExtractableResponse
        Get a single header value associated with the given name. If the header is a multi-value header then you need to use Headers.getList(String) in order to get all values.
        Specified by:

        The header value or null if value was not found.

      • cookies

        public Map<String,String> cookies()
        Description copied from interface: ExtractableResponse
        The response cookies as simple name/value pair. It assumes that no cookies have the same name. If two cookies should never the less have the same name the Last cookie value is used. If you want to return ALL cookies including all the details such as Max-Age etc use ExtractableResponse.detailedCookies().
        Specified by:
        cookies in interface ExtractableResponse<R extends ResponseOptions<R>>
        Returns:
        The response cookies.

      • detailedCookies

        Specified by:
        detailedCookies in interface ExtractableResponse<R extends ResponseOptions<R>>
        Returns:
        The response cookies.

      • as

        public <T> T as(Class<T> cls)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get the body and map it to a Java object. For JSON responses this requires that you have either
        1. Jackson, or
        2. Gson
        in the classpath or for XML responses it requires JAXB to be in the classpath.
        It also requires that the response content-type is either JSON or XML or that a default parser has been been set. You can also force a specific object mapper using ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.as(Class, com.jayway.restassured.mapper.ObjectMapper).
        Specified by:
        as in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Returns:
        The object

      • as

       ObjectMapperType mapperType)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get the body and map it to a Java object using a specific object mapper type. It will use the supplied mapper regardless of the response content-type.
        Specified by:
        as in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Returns:
        The object

      • jsonPath

        public JsonPath jsonPath()
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get a JsonPath view of the response body. This will let you use the JsonPath syntax to get values from the response. Example:

        Assume that the GET request (to http://localhost:8080/lotto) returns JSON as: 

         {
 "lotto":{
   "lottoId":5,
   "winning-numbers":[2,45,34,23,7,5,3],
   "winners":[{
     "winnerId":23,
     "numbers":[2,45,34,23,3,5]
   },{
     "winnerId":54,
     "numbers":[52,3,12,11,18,22]
   }]
  }
 }

        You can the make the request and get the winner id's by using JsonPath: 
         List winnerIds = get("/lotto").jsonPath().getList("lotto.winnders.winnerId");
        Specified by:
        jsonPath in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions

      • jsonPath

        public JsonPath jsonPath(JsonPathConfig config)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get a JsonPath view of the response body using the specified configuration.
        Specified by:
        jsonPath in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Parameters:
        config - The configuration to use
        See Also:
        ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.jsonPath()

      • xmlPath

        public XmlPath xmlPath()
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get an XmlPath view of the response body. This will let you use the XmlPath syntax to get values from the response. Example:

        Imagine that a POST request to http://localhost:8080/greetXML returns: 

         <greeting>
     <firstName>John</firstName>
     <lastName>Doe</lastName>
   </greeting>

        You can the make the request and get the winner id's by using JsonPath: 
         String firstName = get("/greetXML").xmlPath().getString("greeting.firstName");
        Specified by:
        xmlPath in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions

      • xmlPath

        public XmlPath xmlPath(XmlPathConfig config)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get an XmlPath view of the response body with a given configuration.
        Specified by:
        xmlPath in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Parameters:
        config - The configuration of the XmlPath
        See Also:
        ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.xmlPath()

      • xmlPath

        public XmlPath xmlPath(XmlPath.CompatibilityMode compatibilityMode)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get an XmlPath view of the response body but also pass in a XmlPath.CompatibilityMode. This is mainly useful if you want to parse HTML documents.
        Specified by:
        xmlPath in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Parameters:
        compatibilityMode - The compatibility mode to use
        See Also:
        ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.htmlPath(), ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.xmlPath()

      • htmlPath

        public XmlPath htmlPath()
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get an XmlPath view of the response body that uses XmlPath.CompatibilityMode HTML. This is mainly useful when parsing HTML documents.

        Note that this is the same as calling ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.xmlPath(com.jayway.restassured.path.xml.XmlPath.CompatibilityMode) with CompatibilityMode HTML.

        Specified by:
        htmlPath in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions

      • path

        public <T> T path(String path,
         String... arguments)
        Description copied from interface: ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Get a value from the response body using the JsonPath or XmlPath syntax. REST Assured will automatically determine whether to use JsonPath or XmlPath based on the content-type of the response. If no content-type is defined then REST Assured will try to look at the "default parser" if defined (RestAssured.defaultParser).

        Note that you can also also supply arguments, for example: 

         String z = get("/x").path("x.y.%s", "z");
        The path and arguments follows the standard formatting syntax of Java.

        Specified by:
        path in interface ResponseBodyExtractionOptions
        Type Parameters:
        T - The return type
        Parameters:
        path - The json- or xml path
        arguments - Options arguments
        Returns:
        The value returned by the path
        See Also:
        ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.jsonPath(), ResponseBodyExtractionOptions.xmlPath()
